situations.text:
Many sections of the country had reason to be dissatisfied with the existing autocracy. Nicholas II was a deeply conservative ruler and maintained a strict authoritarian system. Individuals and society in general were expected to show self-restraint, devotion to community, deference to the social hierarchy and a sense of duty to the country.
This vision of the Romanov monarchy left him unaware of the state of his country. With a firm belief that his power to rule was granted by Divine Right, Nicholas assumed that the Russian people were devoted to him with unquestioning loyalty. This ironclad belief rendered Nicholas unwilling to allow the progressive reforms that might have alleviated the suffering of the Russian people. Even after the 1905 Revolution spurred the Tsar to decree limited civil rights and democratic representation, he worked to limit even these liberties in order to preserve the ultimate authority of the crown.
Despite constant oppression, the desire of the people for democratic participation in government decisions was strong. Since the Age of Enlightenment, Russian intellectuals had promoted Enlightenment ideals such as the dignity of the individual and the rectitude of democratic representation. These ideals were championed most vociferously by Russia's liberals, although populists, Marxists, and anarchists also claimed to support democratic reforms. A growing opposition movement had begun to challenge the Romanov monarchy openly well before the turmoil of World War I.
Dissatisfaction with Russian autocracy culminated in the huge national upheaval that followed the Bloody Sunday massacre of January 1905, in which hundreds of unarmed protesters were shot by the Tsar's troops. Workers responded to the massacre with a crippling general strike, forcing Nicholas to put forth the October Manifesto, which established a democratically elected parliament (the State Duma). Although the Tsar accepted the anti-democratic 1906 Fundamental State Laws one year later, he subsequently dismissed the first two Dumas when they proved uncooperative. Unfulfilled hopes of democracy fuelled revolutionary ideas and violent outbursts targeted at the monarchy.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_Revolution

questions.text: The following statements about Nicholas II are all true except:
options: He was in favour of progressive reforms
Nicholas II despised a democratic Russia
He was unwilling to maintain democracy at the expense of his monarchy
He did not care much for the suffering of the Russian people
questions.explanation: The 2nd paragraph states that “Nicholas [was] unwilling to allow the progressive reforms…” – we can infer that he was not in favour of progressive reforms. Therefore, the answer is A

questions.text: All of the following are examples of the Tsar’s progressive reforms except:
questions.explanation: In the 4th paragraph it states that “the Tsar accepted the anti-democratic 1906 Fundamental State Laws” – given that we can infer progressive reforms include civil rights and democratic representation (in the 2nd paragraph), we can infer that in being anti-democratic, the Fundamental State Laws are not progressive reforms. Therefore, the answer is D.

questions.text: The Tsar was most likely to support which of the following reforms:
options: Democratic elections for Head of State
questions.explanation: Given that the Tsar reluctantly created a Duma, we can infer that he would most likely support a diminished Duma. All the other 3 options clash with his belief in his “power to rule” and maintaining the autocracy (and are examples of progressive reforms). Therefore, the answer is D.

questions.text: Which of the Tsar’s beliefs and priorities were most likely to have influenced his decision to dismiss the Dumas?
options: Preservation of the crown’s ultimate power at all costs
He was divinely chosen by God to lead, not the Dumas
The people should obey his command no matter what
The Dumas should remain submissive and under his authority
questions.explanation: Given that the Tsar “dismissed the first two Dumas when they proved uncooperative”, we can infer that he would prefer a Duma that was submissive and cooperative with him (ie. under his authority). Therefore, the answer is D.

situations.text:
Adolescence is a crucial period for developing and maintaining social and emotional habits important for mental well-being. These include adopting healthy sleep patterns; taking enough regular exercise; developing coping, problem-solving, and interpersonal skills; and learning to manage emotions. Supportive environments in the family, at school and in the wider community are also important. An estimated 10–20% of adolescents globally experience mental health conditions, yet these remain underdiagnosed and undertreated.
Multiple factors determine mental health outcomes. The more risk factors adolescents are exposed to, the greater the potential impact on their mental health. Factors that can contribute to stress during adolescence include a desire for greater autonomy, pressure to conform with peers, exploration of sexual identity, and increased access to and use of technology. Media influence and gender norms can exacerbate the disparity between an adolescent’s lived reality and their perceptions or aspirations for the future. Other important determinants include the quality of their home life and relationships with peers. Violence (including harsh parenting) and socioeconomic problems are recognized risks to mental health. Children and adolescents are especially vulnerable to sexual violence, which has a clear association with detrimental mental health.
Some adolescents are at greater risk of mental health conditions due to their living conditions, stigma, discrimination or exclusion, or lack of access to quality support and services. These include adolescents living in humanitarian and fragile settings; adolescents with chronic illness, autism spectrum disorder, an intellectual disability or other neurological condition; pregnant adolescents, adolescent parents, or those in early and/or forced marriages; orphans; and adolescents from minority ethnic or sexual backgrounds or other discriminated groups.
Source: https://www.who.int/

questions.text: All the following are important habits for maintaining adolescent mental health except
questions.explanation: The 1st paragraph states that maintain adolescent mental health involves “adopting healthy sleep patterns” – however practising consistent sleeping choices is not exactly the same thing (you could consistently sleep for 1 hour a day and that would not be a healthy sleep pattern). Communication and social skills are a subset of interpersonal skills, therefore A is not correct. Therefore, the answer is D.

questions.text: Mental health outcomes for adolescents are influenced by all of the following except
options: Social pressure to be like those around them
Increased use of phones and computers
questions.explanation: In the 2nd paragraph it states that factors that can contribute to stress during adolescence include “greater autonomy” (independence), “pressure to conform with peers” (social pressure to be like those around them) and “increased access to and use of technology” (phones and computers). Although “exploration of sexual identity” (ie. sexual orientation etc) is included, that is not the same thing as “longing for sexual activity”. Therefore, the answer is C.

questions.text: The most likely reason for children and adolescents being more exposed to mental health issues is that
options: They are more innocent and naïve
They receive violent punishments from their parents
They don’t have access to proper care and help
They are always exposed to bullying online and in-person
questions.explanation: In the 3rd paragraph it states that “some adolsecents are at greater risk of mental health conditions due to … [a] lack of access to quality support and services”. Therefore, the answer is C.

questions.text: Which of the following explanations for adolescents being at greater risk of mental health issues is most likely to be false?
options: They don’t have any kind of support or access to help services
They face stereotypes and a lack of adolescent mental health awareness
They are discriminated and excluded socially
They don’t have time to discuss their issues
questions.explanation: Of all the 4 options, only option D is not mentioned in the passage. Therefore, the answer is D. (In the 3rd paragraph: A – “lack of access to quality support and services”, B – “stigma”, C – “discrimination or exclusion”).

situations.text: Some laptops can fold in half, but not all the laptops that can fold in half are touchscreen. All phones are touchscreen as well.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Some touchscreen laptops can fold in half
Some phones can fold in half
If a phone can fold in half will also be touchscreen
Some laptops can fold in half but not be touchscreen
questions.explanation:
1. We do not know that a laptop that can fold in half is definitely touchscreen (‘not all’ only means not 100%, but it also includes 0/none). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. We don’t have any information about phones folding in half. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. Since all phones are touchscreen, one that can fold in half will also be touchscreen. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
4. ‘Not all’ implies that at least 1 laptop that can fold in half is not touchscreen. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. We don’t even know if one laptop that can fold in half is touchscreen for sure. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

situations.text: Some Pops are Paps. All Pips are Pups. No Pips are Pops. Most Pops are Peps. Some Paps are Peps.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Some Paps that are Peps could be Pops
questions.explanation:
1. If all Pips are Pups, then we know at least some Pups are Pips too, which means these Pups cannot be Pops. But the trail stops there and we do not know for sure whether these Pups or Pups in general are Peps. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. We do not know the proportion of Paps that are Peps – only that some Paps are Peps (there could only be 1 Pap that is a Pep). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. There is nothing to suggest that all Pups cannot be Paps. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. If all Pips are Pups, then we know at least some Pups are Pips too, which means these Pups cannot be Pops, however we do not know about the Pups that are not Pips. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. Since most Pops are Peps, the Paps that are Peps COULD be Pops (but we don’t know for certain). Since the statement is phrased like ‘these particular Paps COULD be Pops’, the correct answer is YES.

situations.text: Snakes only eat frogs and fish. Both frogs and fish eat insects, but a fish that has eaten an insect cannot be eaten by a snake. Snakes, frogs and fish die if they do not eat.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: If a snake eats something, it must be a frog
If a fish eats an insect, it cannot be eaten by anything
If the frogs eat all the insects, snakes will only eat fish
If the frogs and fish disappear, the snakes will die
A snake could eat an insect
questions.explanation:
1. It could have eaten a fish. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. All we know is that it can’t be eaten by a snake, but we don’t know if anything else eats the fish. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. The snakes could still eat the frogs, but all this means is that snakes will always be able to eat the fish since they can’t eat insects. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. Since the snakes only eat frogs and fish and will die if they do not eat, the snakes will die if the frogs and fish disappear. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. A snake can only eat frogs and fish. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

situations.text: All acrobats are bald. Some bald people are dancers. All clowns are acrobats as well.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Some acrobats can be bald and a clown
Not all clowns who are acrobats are bald
A clown who is a dancer must be bald
questions.explanation:
1. Some acrobats are clowns (as all clowns are acrobats), and all acrobats are bald. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
2. We don’t know if clowns are dancers for sure. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. Just because some dancers are bald does not mean that some have to be acrobats. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. All clowns who are acrobats must be bald as all acrobats are bald. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. Since all clowns are acrobats and all acrobats must be bald, the clown must be bald anyway. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text: This object is green. Some green things are found outside.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: All objects that are green must be found outside
All green things must be objects
If an object is found outside, it must be green
This object could be found outside
questions.explanation:
1. Only some green things are found outside, so we cannot be certain that this object was found outside. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. Only some green things are found outside, so we cannot say that all objects that are green must be found outside. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. We do not know whether this is true as all we know is that this one object is green. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. We don’t know that all the objects found outside are green. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. Given that this object is green and some green things are found outside, this object COULD be found outside. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text:
Three friends buy ice-cream with toppings, with flavours of either chocolate, vanilla, choc-chip or lemon.
Nima gets the chocolate flavoured ice-cream.
The vanilla flavoured ice-cream cannot have sprinkles as toppings.
The sprinkles were on two different ice-creams, but cannot be put on a lemon flavoured ice-cream.
Ken does not like sprinkles or lemon.

questions.text: Which ice-cream flavour was not chosen?
questions.explanation: We know that the chocolate flavour was chosen. Since vanilla flavoured ice-cream cannot have sprinkles, and the sprinkles were on two difference ice-creams except chocolate, we can conclude that the sprinkles were on the chocolate and choc-chip ice-cream – meaning that the choc-chip was chosen. If Ken does not like sprinkles, he could have chosen lemon or vanilla, but since he doesn’t like lemon he must have chosen vanilla. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

situations.text:
Immunisations expire 8 months after they are given.
At School X, students are given immunisation Y in July every year.
Felix got his immunisation Y in May earlier this year before he changed schools.
Someone cannot have more than 1 immunisation within a 6 month period.
Students must be immunised at all times.

questions.text: Which of the following MUST be true?
options: Felix can get another immunisation with the school in July this year
Felix will have to go 6 months without an immunisation next year
Felix will have to get 3 immunisations minimum next year
Felix cannot have his next immunisation with School X
questions.explanation: Since Felix got his immunisation in May, the earliest he can get his next one is around November – since School X immunises students with immunisation Y in July, Felix cannot have his next immunisation with the school. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

situations.text:
Andy, Bingo, Cam, Drake and Eli have a car each. The cars are either green, orange or red in colour.
Three cars are sedans and the rest are 4WDs.
None of the 4WDs are green.
Bingo and Eli do not own orange cars but drive sedans.
Andy loves to drive around his orange sedan.

questions.text: Which of the following MUST be true?
options: Cam does not drive an orange car
questions.explanation: There are 2 4WDs. All the sedans are orange (owned by Bingo, Eli and Andy). Thus Drake and Cam own the 2 4WDs. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

situations.text:
Four friends decided to meet up for coffee after not having seen each other for a while, scheduling a meet-up at 5:00pm.
Jerome was the only person to come on time.
Irina came after Jerome but before Henry.
Lawson arrived 10 minutes late due to traffic.
Rebecca and Lawson drove together and saw Henry behind them in traffic.

questions.text: Who could have arrived before Lawson?
questions.explanation: Jerome came at 5.00pm. Lawson and Rebecca arrived at 5.10pm. Henry arrived after Lawson and Rebecca, and after Irina. We do not know if Irina arrived before Lawson/Rebecca or after them, however it is a possibility that she arrived before them. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

situations.text: Keagan has a bunch of highlighters; yellow, green and pink. All the highlighters of the same colour have the same height. One day in school, he is bored and decides to stack them up to see how high he can get them. He manages to stack 2 yellow highlighters, 2 green highlighters and 2 pink highlighters that reached a height of 40cm before it falls down. He then manages to stack 3 yellow highlighters, 3 green highlighters and 2 pink highlighters to a height of 50cm before it falls down again. Which of the following is the height of a stack that contains 5 yellow highlighters, 5 green highlighters and 3 pink highlighters?

questions.explanation: You can make 3 equations from this question: (1) 2y + 2g + 2p = 40, (2) 3y + 3g + 2p = 50, (3) 5y + 5g + 3p = ?. We can convert (1) and (2) to 2p = 40 – 2y – 2g, and 2p = 50 – 3y – 3g. Using simultaneous equations, we can equate these rearranged equations to 40 – 2y – 2g = 50 – 3y – 3g, and simplify the equation so that 10 = y + g. Now we can multiple this by 2 so we get 20 = 2y + 2g, and substitute this into (1) so that 20 + 2p = 40, so therefore p = 10. We can also multiple 10 = y + g by 5 to get 50 = 5y + 5g to substitute into the last equation, so that 50 + 3p = ?. Since we know p=10, we can solve the equation to be 80. Therefore, the correct answer is A. ALTERNATIVELY, you can guess the answer after finding the equation 10 = y + g. If you multiply this by 5 to sub into the last equation so you get 50 + 3p = ?, you can guess that the answer has to be lower than 90 (because if 2y + 2g + 2p = 40, then how can 3p = 40 for 50 + 3p = 90?). Since the only answer below 90 is A, the answer you will get is A.

situations.text: Should alcohol-serving venues check whether a patron is driving before they serve them more than the safe limit for drinking, in order to reduce drink-driving accidents?

options: Yes, 80% of lives lost on the roads are due to drink-driving accidents
Yes, most drink-driving accidents occur on the way back from having alcohol at an alcohol-serving venue like a bar
No, the safe limit for drinking is different for everyone so would be hard to implement
No, this would be terrible for business
questions.explanation: Option A and B are the only two that address the problem of drink-driving accidents which is raised in the question, however B provides a logical explanation as to why the proposed solution will work whereas A does not address the alcohol-serving venues as mentioned in the question. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

situations.text: Should the government make vaccines mandatory for the population in order to reduce rates of disease and infection?

options: Yes, low rates of disease and infection have been shown to rely on more people being vaccinated
Yes, the government has a responsibility to protect the interests of the population
No, people have a right to do what they want to do
No, because some people may have an allergic reaction to certain vaccines
questions.explanation: Option A is the only one that uses evidence, and addresses the problem raised in the question which is the need to reduce rates of disease and infection. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

situations.text: Should the use of mobile phones when walking be banned to prevent jay-walking accidents, where people get hit on the road?

options: Yes, 50% of pedestrian-car collisions occur due to the pedestrian being distracted by their phone
Yes, people are too addicted to their mobile phones and it would be healthy for them
No, people have a right to use their phones when they like
No, this would be too difficult to enforce and implement
questions.explanation: The problem raised in this question is the need to reduce jay-walking accidents, and option A is the only option that addresses this problem and justifies the relevance of mobile phones with evidence. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

situations.text: Should prospective dog owners have to go a stringent checking and vetting process before they get a dog in order to reduce the number of dogs being sent to the pound and abandoned?

options: Yes, most abandoned dogs come from homes where they were receiving inappropriate treatment and care
Yes, people need to be held accountable for their actions
No, this would deter many prospective dog owners from getting a dog if they had to undergo such stringent measures
No, people who want a dog should be able to get it
questions.explanation: The problem raised in this question is the need to reduce the number of dogs being sent to the pound, and so option A states that the problem is most of these dogs come from homes with poor treatment and so this solution of checking more thoroughly would therefore have an impact on the number of dogs sent to the pound. Therefore, the correct answer is A. Option C seems reasonable but does not address the problem of reducing dogs at the pound.

situations.text:
The following bar graph shows the number of pints of beer sold at a certain bar in a year, and the types of brands that were sold. Each brand of beer costs $5.50 per pint. Last year sales were much worse.
Source: https://sites.google.com/site/mathclc/graphs

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Sales this year for the bar were, on average, quite good
Duff Original is a more popular brand of beer than Bud Light
If the bar’s costs for stocking Duff Original were 1 million dollars this year, they earned $540,000 profit
The bar sells 8 types of beers
Next year, sales are likely to go up again as well
questions.explanation:
1. We don’t know what classified as ‘good’ for the sales at this bar. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. At this particular bar Duff Original has more sales, but that doesn’t mean it is more popular in general than Bud Light. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. The total revenue earned at this bar from Duff Original is 280,000*5.50 = 1,540,000. If the costs were 1,000,000, then the remaining profit is 540,000 dollars. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
4. The bar sells 7 types of beers + the ‘other’ category, and we don’t know how many beers fall under that. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. We don’t know what is going to happen next year, this would be predicting which we cannot do from the information in this graph. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

situations.text:
Cancer is the second leading cause of death globally, and is responsible for 9.6 million deaths in 2018. Globally, 1 in 6 deaths is due to cancer. Approximately 70% of deaths from cancer occur in low- and middle-income countries. Cancer arises from the transformation of normal cells into tumour cells in a multistage process that generally progresses from a pre-cancerous lesion to a malignant tumour. Ageing is another fundamental factor for the development of cancer. The incidence of cancer rises dramatically with age, most likely due to a build-up of risks for specific cancers that increase with age. The overall risk accumulation is combined with the tendency for cellular repair mechanisms to be less effective as a person grows older.
Source: https://www.who.int/

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: The leading cause of death in the world will have resulted in more than 9.6 million deaths in 2018
In 2018, approximately 57.6 million people died in the world
Close to 6.72 million people from low-income countries died of cancer
An older person is generally more likely to get cancer than a child
Cellular repair mechanisms tend to become less useful as a person ages
questions.explanation:
1. If cancer is the second leading cause of death and is responsible for 9.6 million deaths in 2018, the leading cause of death must have been responsible for more deaths. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
2. If 9.6 million people died from cancer in 2018 and 1/6 deaths are due to cancer, then 9.6 million * 6 = 57.6 million people died in the world in 2018. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. 0.70 * 9.6 million = 6.72 million people. However, 70% represents low and middle income countries, so we can’t say that all these deaths were just from low income countries. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. Since the “incidence of cancer rises dramatically with age”, we can infer that an older person is more likely in general to get cancer than a child. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. Since “the overall risk accumulation is combined with the tendency for cellular repair mechanisms to be less effective as a person grows older”, we can infer that they are not as useful (less effective) as a person ages. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text:
A total of 400 students at Jinabong High School were surveyed to see what genre of movie they liked, in order to decide which genre of movie they would watch at the school’s next movie night.
Source: https://sites.google.com/site/mathclc/graphs

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: More than a quarter of the students preferred Romance or Drama
At the next movie night, they will be watching a comedy movie
Action is a more popular genre amongst these students than Horror
The same number of students like Science Fiction, Drama and Foreign films as those who like Comedy films
16 more students liked Action movies over Drama movies
questions.explanation:
1. Romance + Drama = 14% + 14% = 28%, which is more than a quarter (25%). Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
2. That is making an assumption that just because it is the most popular choice, it will get chosen at the next movie night. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. 18% prefer action whereas 11% prefer horror. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
4. Science fiction + Drama + Foreign = 30%, Comedy = 27%. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. 18% - 14% = 4%. 4% of 400 students is 16. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text:
Company A is planning its 2020 budget. In order to allocate its resources appropriately it reviews the amount of money spent on drinks (actual) compared to the money allocated for it (budget) in 2019. The y-axis shows the number of dollars spent on each item.
Source: https://peltiertech.com/clustered-stacked-column-bar-charts/

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: More money was spent on coffee than allocated in 2019
More money should be allocated for milk in 2020
If coffee costs $4 per a packet, approximately 1000 packets were bought in 2019
Out of these three options, coffee cost the most money for Company A
Tea is the only condiment that required more money in 2019 than the money allocated for it.
questions.explanation:
1. The Actual bar is higher in total than the Budget bar for Coffee (both quarters as this is for the whole year of 2019). Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
2. The budget for milk for the whole year is greater than what was spent. Furthermore, we do not know if the company will even buy milk in 2020 for example, as this would be making a judgement beyond the data in the graph. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. $4000 was spent on coffee in 2019, which means 1000 packets of coffee were bought for $4 each. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
4. The Actual bar for coffee (whole year) is higher than the other 2 drinks by observation. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. Coffee also required more money than was allocated. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

situations.text:
The bar chart above demonstrates the sum awards won by directors in various genres, with the results collated from an independent survey. Some directors chose not to respond.
Source: https://docs.mongodb.com/charts/master/chart-type-reference/column-bar-chart/

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Steven Spielberg has won awards in more genres than any other director
At least 3 directors surveyed have won over 300 awards each.
If each award was accompanied by a $20 prize, Ang Lee would have $40000 in cash prizes.
From those who responded to the survey, the greatest number of awards in comedy has gone to Lee Unkrich
David Fincher and Curtis Hanson have collaborated on several projects, as seen by their similar award achievements.
questions.explanation:
1. Given that some directors chose not to respond, we don’t know for sure whether Steven Spielberg has won award in more genres than any other director. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. Ethan/Joel Coen, Lee Unkrich and Steven Spielberg have won more than 300 awards each. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. Ang Lee has won 200 awards, so 200*20 = $4000, not $40,000. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. He has won about 100 comedy awards, and the only other surveyed director to have won a comedy award or come close is Roberto Benigni with less than 100, maybe 50. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. We cannot tell what awards correlate to which projects, so this would be an assumption. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

situations.text: In a bar they serve 2 drinks, Drink A and Drink B. They only served 30 drinks in total one night, and equal amounts of Drink A and Drink B. Eight of the Drink B drinks had sugar, whereas 13 of the Drink A drinks did not have sugar.

questions.text: How many more drinks have sugar than do not have sugar?
questions.explanation: 15 of each drink was sold that night, so 8 of Drink B had sugar so 7 did not, and 2 of Drink A had sugar and 13 did not. Therefore in total 10 had sugar and 20 did not. So the difference is 10. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

situations.text: A local golf club sells 2 types of golf clubs, drivers and putters, in two colours, gold and silver. In one week they told 40 clubs. Seventeen of the 19 putters sold were in silver, however all the drivers sold were in gold.

questions.text: How many gold golf clubs were sold?
questions.explanation: If 19 putters were sold then 21 drivers must have been sold. If 17 putters were in silver than 2 must have been in gold. Therefore 21 + 2 = 23 gold golf clubs. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

situations.text: Fifty people went to get tested for a certain disease. Half of the people who went to get tested received a positive result, however 40% of the results that showed positive were false positives (incorrect results). If there were 20 results for negative that were true negatives (correct results), how many people received incorrect results?

questions.explanation: If half of 50 got a positive, then 40% of 25 = 10 people who got false positives. If 20 people who got negative got true negatives, then 5 people got false negatives. 10 + 5 = 15. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

situations.text: A bakery sells many different types of bread. The bread can be either hard-crusted or soft crusted and a quick seller or unpopular variety.

questions.text: Which of the following combinations doesn’t exist?
options: An unpopular loaf that is hard crusted
An unpopular loaf that is soft crusted
A quick selling loaf that is soft crusted
A quick selling loaf that is hard crusted
questions.explanation: The diamond (quick seller) and crescent (soft crusted) do not overlap. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

situations.text: A candy maker makes lollipops with different colour combinations.

questions.text: Which of the following is represented by the question mark?
questions.explanation: The question mark is in the overlap between the triangle (blue), oval (yellow), and rectangle (green). Therefore, the correct answer is C.

situations.text: Company Y and X both sell a detergent. For Company X, 20% of customers return their product but 60% of their total stock is sold initially. For Company Y, 3 in 8 customers choose to return their product but 80% of their stock gets sold initially. Assume both companies have the same amount of stock for the same price, and customers all buy the same amount of product. Which Company sold more of its stock?

options: Company X, as only 12% of stock is returned
Company X, as they get less returns
Company Y, as they sell a greater proportion of their products overall
Company Y, as they sell a greater proportion of their products initially
questions.explanation: Company X ultimately sells 40% of its products after returns, and Company Y sells 42.5% of its stock after returns. Therefore, Company Y sold more of their stock as they sell a greater proportion of their products overall. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

situations.text: A fair coin is tossed and a 6-sided die are rolled at the same time. What is the probability that a heads and an even number are achieved?

questions.explanation: Probability of a heads is 0.5, and probability of an even number is 3/6 = 0.5 as well. Therefore 0.5*0.5 = 0.25 = 1/4. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

situations.text: Kenny and Lenny play a game where they roll a die that is biased towards certain numbers, and the winner is the one who rolls a 5 first. The probability of getting a 3, 4 or 5 is double that of the other numbers. Kenny rolls first. Do they both have the same chance of winning?

options: Yes, as they are both using the same biased die
Yes, the biased nature of the dice doesn’t affect the numbers rolled
No, as Lenny can only win if Kenny loses on his turn
No, Kenny has a higher chance of winning as the numbers are biased
questions.explanation: Since Kenny goes first, and the winner is the first person to get a 5, Kenny has a greater chance of winning (he can win on the first turn without Lenny even having a turn). Therefore, the correct answer is C.

situations.text: Hospital X only has 30 emergency beds, whereas Hospital Y has 40 emergency beds. Hospital Y can boost its supplies with an extra 30 beds from its supply of 200, whereas Hospital X can boost its supplies with an extra 50 beds from its supply of 150. Which hospital should boost its supplies of emergency beds, keeping in mind that their total supply of beds is required in use for the rest of the hospital?

options: Hospital X – they only take a third of their total supply of beds to boost emergency bed numbers
Hospital X – they can get 10 more emergency beds than Hospital Y
Hospital Y – they have a greater supply to boost from
Hospital Y – they only take 15% of their total bed supply to boost emergency bed numbers and only have 10 less beds initially than Hospital X
questions.explanation: Hospital X can take 15% of its supply to have 60 emergency beds, whereas Hospital Y can take 1/3 of its supply (33.33%) to have 90 emergency beds. Of the 4 options presented, option D is the most reasonable as a lower percentage of the overall supply it taken by hospital X. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

situations.text: Jacob and Fred play a game where they both toss a coin. The second person loses if they both get the same side of the coin as the first person, and they win if they get different sides. Jacob tosses first and gets a head. Has Fred’s chance of winning on his toss changed?

options: No, what Jacob tosses does not influence his own toss
No, it is still 0.25, hasn’t changed from before
questions.explanation: Fred’s chance of winning is 50% and losing is 50% still, regardless of what Jacob tossed. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

situations.text: The following graph shows the distance travelled by a person on their bike to and from their house over a 30 second time period (at the 30 second mark they did not make it back home).

questions.text: What was the biker’s average speed for the first 7 seconds, to the nearest whole number?
questions.explanation: At 7 seconds the biker travelled 80m, therefore using the formula s = d/t = 80/7 = 11.42…m/s = 11m/s (average speed). Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: At which of the following time intervals has he been travelling at an average speed 12m/s?
questions.explanation: At 10 seconds he has travelled 120 metres, thus the average speed over those 10 seconds would be 120/10 = 12m/s.

questions.text: If the biker did another 30 second ride but on a different route, but his speed consistently matched the same average speed he travelled between 10 and 15 seconds of his original 30 seconds, how far did he travel the second time around?
questions.explanation: In 10-15 seconds, he travelled 20m (140-120 = 20). Therefore, his average speed during those 5 seconds would have been 20/5 = 4m/s. Therefore, if he travelled 30 seconds at this speed, his distance covered would be 30*4 = 120m. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

questions.text: How far did the biker travel over the 30 seconds?
questions.explanation: After 15 seconds he was 140m away from his house, and from 15-30 seconds he travelled about 90m back. Therefore, 140 + 90 = 230m in total. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

situations.text: The following graph highlights several mental disorders and the annual percentage of patients who came into a certain hospital from 1985 to 2005.

questions.text: If 5% of patients had OCD in 1985, by how much did the percentage of patients with Bipolar increase from 1990 to 1995?
questions.explanation: Bipolar 1990 = 5%. Bipolar 1995 = 10%. Therefore, there was a 5% increase. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: If 185,000 patients came to the hospital in 2000, how many of these patients had anxiety?
questions.explanation: 185,000*0.30 = 55,500. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: If there were 1,300 patients who came into the hospital in 1985 with depression, how many patients came in with anxiety in the same year?
questions.explanation: If 1,300 patients came in with depression in 1985 (60%), then the total amount of patients = 1,300/0.60 = 2,166.66… .Therefore, number of anxiety patients in 1985 = 0.30*2,166.66… = 650. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: In how many years were the number of Bipolar and OCD patients coming to the hospital the same?
questions.explanation: From 1985-1990 and during one year in between 2000 and 2005, the two lines for Bipolar and OCD intersect/overlap. Therefore, we know there were the same number of patients for both for 7 years. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

situations.text: The following graph shows the acceptance rate (%) of college applications to College X from 2000 to 2007. In 2004, 250 students applied to College X.

questions.text: If the number of students who applied to College X increased by 20% from 2004 to 2006, how many students got accepted in 2006?
questions.explanation: If the number of applicants increased by 20% from 250 in 2004 to 2006, then in 2006 the number of applicants would be 300. In 2006, however, the acceptance rate was at 50%. Therefore, only 150 applicants were accepted. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: If the same number of students applied to College X in 2004 and 2007, how many fewer students were accepted in 2007 than in 2001?
questions.explanation: In 2004, the acceptance rate was 90% whereas in 2007, the acceptance rate was 20%. There is a 70% difference in acceptance rates, and if the number of students remained the same in both years, then the difference in numbers = 0.70*250 = 175 students. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: If 600 students got accepted into College X in 2002, but how much did the number of students who applied change from 2002 to 2004?
questions.explanation: If 600 students got accepted in 2002 at a rate of 75%, then the total who applied would be 600/0.75 = 800 total. Therefore, the difference between 800 students applying in 2002 and 250 students applying in 2004 is a decrease in 550 students applying to College X. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: If the same number of students apply to College X every year, what is the percentage decrease from the number of students who got accepted in 2001 to those who got accepted in 2007?
questions.explanation: If every year has the same number of applicants, let’s just say that there were 100 applicants for simplicity. Therefore, in 2001, 0.40*100 = 40 applicants were accepted. In 2007, 0.20*100 = 20 applicants were accepted. Thus, we can see that there was a (40 – 20)/40 = 50% decrease in applicants from 2001-2007. Therefore, the correct answer is C (alternatively you can just look at the percentages and see that 20% is half of 40% etc, but some people may find it easier to thing of it in numbers rather than percentage).

situations.text: The following graph shows the reasons why people did not report a crime to the police. A total of 100,000 people did not report a crime to the police.

questions.text: How many people who did not report a crime to the police stated why they didn’t?
questions.explanation: Did not state why = 24%, therefore we know 76% did state why. Therefore, 100,000*0.76 = 76,000. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: How many more people did not report a crime to the police because they police would do nothing about it than those who did not have insurance?
questions.explanation: Police would do nothing about it = 6%. No insurance = 1%. Therefore we can see there is a 5% difference here. Thus, 5% of 100,000 = 5,000. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: What is the ratio of people who did not report a crime to the police because the perpetrator was known to them to those who had other reasons?
questions.explanation: Perpetrator was known to me = 2%. Other reasons = 10%. The ratio of 2%:10% = 2:10 = 1:5. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: If the police encouraged all those who thought their crime was not serious enough to be reported to report all these crimes, but the percentage of those who did not state why remains the same, how many people now did not state why?
questions.explanation: Not serious enough/no loss = 17%, and 17% of 100,000 is 17,000. Therefore if all these people reported the crime to the police, only 83,000 people would remain. Thus, if the percentage of those who did not state why remains the same, then 24% of 83,000 = 19,920 people who did not state why. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

situations.text: The diagram below shows the plans for a house going to be built. Note that the builders only have 148m of wood to build the frame of the house with (not including the door, only the walls, floor and roof). It is not to scale. Note that the centre of the roof is aligned with the centre of the front wall.

questions.text: The width and the height of the door are in a 2:3 ratio. How much plaster would the builder need for the front wall of the house, if it was to cover the entire wall area?
questions.explanation: Total area of the front of the house (inc. door) = 6*4 = 24m2. Width of the door has to be 1m, if it is in a 2:3 ratio with the 1.5m height. Therefore, the area of the door is 1*1.5 = 1.5m2. Therefore the area of the front wall of the house without the door is 24 – 1.5 = 22.5m2. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: How much wood is required to build the triangular frames of the roof, for only the front of the house?
questions.explanation: Bottom edge of the triangle is 1+6+1 = 8m long, therefore, using the formula for finding the diagonal, b = 4m, and a = 3m from the diagram. Thus, c2 = 9 + 16 = 25. Thus, c = 5m (since c cannot be -5). Therefore the perimeter of the frame = 5 + 5 + 8 = 18m. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

questions.text: How long (depth) can the house possibly be at a maximum, assuming the wood needed to build the frame in between the two faces of the house is connected to the 7 vertices of this diagram of the front of the house (dotted line)? (don’t include the door frame)
questions.explanation: The roof frame calculated in Q18 is 18m, and we can calculate the rest of the perimeter of the front to be 4 + 6 + 4 = 14m. Therefore the wood needed for the front of the house is 18 + 14 = 32m. The back will also be 32m. Since only 148m of wood is available, we have 148 – 32 – 32 = 84m for the length. Since we have 7 vertices to connect, 84/7 = 12m for each one. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: If the front door is 1m wide, what is the maximum number of 2m x 2m windows can the builder put into the front of the house on the front wall?
questions.explanation: The remaining wall space after the door is (4*6) – (1*1.5) = 22.5m2. The space either side of the door is 2.5m wide, therefore you can only have 1 window on either side of the door, lengthways. In terms of height, since the wall is 4m tall, you could technically have 2 windows vertically on either side. However, there is a space on top of the door, meaning you could have 3 windows lengthways above the door height and then 2 windows next to the door on either side. Thus, the maximum number of windows you could have is 5. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

situations.text: James drives his car at a speed of 30km/h on suburban roads, however he must slow down to 10km/h when driving over speedbumps. It takes him 10 seconds to drive over a speed bump. Assume that he can instantaneously reduce his speed.

questions.text: If he is driving down a suburban road with 4 speed bumps for 5 minutes, how far does he go approximately, to the closest value below?
questions.explanation: If he drives over 4 speed bumps, that’s 40 seconds it takes him in total to go over them at 10km/h – therefore we can calculate that the distance he travelled over the speed bumps is d = s*t = 10*(40/60/60) = 0.1111km. The distance for the remaining 4 minutes and 20 seconds: d = s*t = 30*(4.3333/60) = 2.1666km. Therefore, in total 0.111+2.1666 = 2.2777…km. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

questions.text: James can travel twice as fast on city roads, however he has to stop for 3 minutes at any traffic light. One day James drives 10km in the city, stopping at 3 traffic lights. How long did he spend driving?
questions.explanation: If he drives at 60km/h in the city, and he drives 10km, he spent t = d/s = 10/60 = 0.1666 hours = 10 minutes driving. If he has to stop at 3 traffic lights for 3 minutes, that’s an extra 9 minutes, adding to make 19 minutes total. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

situations.text: The following graph shows the depreciation (decrease) in the value of Sally’s car as the years progressed following her purchase of the car in 2001.

questions.text: What is the percentage depreciation of Sally’s car in the first year?
questions.explanation: 24,000 – 22,500 = $1,500. Therefore % depreciation is 1,500/24,000 * 100 = 6.25%. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

questions.text: What is the average rate of percentage annual depreciation from 2004-2007, to the nearest whole percent?
If she added a new engine to her car in 2006 which increased the value of the car by 25%, but the percentage depreciation remained the same, what would the value of her car be in 2007?
questions.explanation: 1.25*10,000 = $12,500 after the new engine. The percentage depreciation from 2006-07 = (10,000-5,800)/5,800 = 0.42 = 42%. Therefore 12,500 * 0.58 = $7,250 (1 – 0.42 = 0.58). Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: If Sally wants to sell her car before at loses more than 50% of its value, how much does she lose off the original price of the car?
questions.explanation: A 50% loss of value would be $12,000. Thus she has to sell it before in 2005, so 24,000 – 14,500 = $9,500. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

situations.text: The two pie charts below show how the popularity of certain transport modes in Cambridge has changed from 2008 to 2018. The figures are in percentages. The same number of people were in Cambridge in 2008 and 2018.

questions.text: What proportion of all the people who rode bicycles in 2008 and 2018 combined rode in bicycles 2008?
questions.explanation: People riding bicycles in 2008 and 2018 = 17 + 30 = 47 (assuming for the sake of working out that there are 100 people in 2008 and 2018). Therefore 17/47 = 0.3617… = 0.36. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: If 10,000 people were in Cambridge in 2008, how many more people drove cars in 2008 compared to 2018?
questions.explanation: Cars in 2008 = 0.42 * 10,000 = 4,200. Cars in 2018 = 0.20 * 10,000 = 2,000. There is a 2,200 difference. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: How many forms of transport experienced an increase in user numbers from 2008 to 2018?
questions.explanation: Bicycles and Buses experienced a user increase (we can use the percentages as a guide on the chart because the population remained the same). Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: What is the ratio of people riding busses in 2008 to those riding a bicycle in 2018, if there were three times as many people in Cambridge in 2018 than 2008?
questions.explanation: Since there is an equal proportion of people using busses in 2008 to bicycles in 2018 (30%), if the population in 2018 is 3 times bigger than that of 2008, we know the ratio will be 1:3 (Busses 2008: Bicycles 2018). Therefore, the correct answer is A.

situations.text: The table below compared the number of people smoking and their weights, organizing them by degrees of smoking and weight, in a survey.

questions.text: What proportion of non-smokers are overweight, to the closest value below?
questions.explanation: Number of overweight non-smokers = 2499 – 53 – 543 = 1,903. Therefore the proportion is 1,903/2499 = 0.7615… . Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: How many people were surveyed?
questions.explanation: We know 42 people are missing from the data, therefore 5167+42 = 5,209 people in total responded to this survey. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: What is the average number of people across all smoking categories who are underweight, to the closest person?
questions.explanation: Since the total of underweight people is 178, we can find the average by dividing that by 5: 178/5 = 35.6 = 36. Therefore, the correct answer is B, to the nearest person.

questions.text: What percentage of the people who responded to the survey were very heavy smokers or overweight?
questions.explanation: Very Heavy smokers = 469, Overweight = 3527, Heavy smokers and Overweight = 325. Therefore the total number of heavy smokers or overweight = 469 + 3527 – 325 = 3,671. If the total number of respondees was 5,167 + 42 = 5,209, then the percentage of the heavy smokers or overweight people in the survey = 3,671/5,209 * 100 = 70.47…%. Therefore, the correct answer is A, to the nearest percent.

questions.text: Joe bought 4 kilograms of apples at the cost of $15. How much would he pay for 11 kilograms of the same apples in the same shop?
questions.explanation: 15/4 = $3.75/kg for the apples. Therefore 3.75 * 11 = $41.25 for 11 kg. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: The distance between two cities on the map is 15 centimetres. The scales on the map is 1.25 centimetres to 15 kilometres. What is the real distance, in kilometres, between the two cities?
questions.explanation: 15cm/1.25cm = 12 times greater. Thus, 12 * 15km = 180km. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

situations.text: Chris, a medical student, is out with two other students, James and Janette, at a social event. They are all friends. At the event, Janette makes what Chris believes to be an inappropriate comment to James. James appears offended. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Chris in this situation?

questions.text: Immediately apologise to James on behalf of Janette
questions.explanation: Having noticed that James is upset, Chris may feel compelled to apologise. While this may help comfort James, Chris is not the one who made the comment and, instead, Janette should be encouraged to apologise

questions.text: Later, speak to Janette privately about how her comment appeared to offend James
questions.explanation: Waiting until later to speak to Janette allows both parties to calm down and privately informing her of how James may have been offended is a respectful, non-confrontational approach to the issue

questions.text: Later, speak to Janette in front of James about how her comment appeared to offend James
questions.explanation: While not terrible privately informing her of how James may have been offended is a respectful, non-confrontational approach to the issue

questions.text: Immediately ask Janette to apologise to James
questions.explanation: While this recognises the fact that James has been offended by the comment, ask Janette to apologise immediately is a confrontation way to address the issue and may inflame the situation

questions.text: Privately ask James how he felt about the comment
questions.explanation: This response displays empathy towards James and may help clarify whether he was in fact offended by the comment

situations.text: At a hospital, a medical student, Sam, is called by another medical student, Sureshma, who is working in another ward. Sureshma asks if Sam can send the records of a patient to her. That patient is Sureshma’s cousin and she would like to know how he is. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Sam in this situation?

questions.text: Sorry Sureshma, I am not allowed to send patient information
questions.explanation: Patient confidentiality is essential and should be upheld by doctors and patients. Others can only ever access patient information if they are directly involved in the treatment and their care

questions.text: Why don't you visit or call your cousin when free, to see how he is?
questions.explanation: This response would prevent a breach of patient confidentiality and data protection rules. It provides a practical solution and is sensitive to Sureshma’s concern.

questions.text: I’ll send the file over now
questions.explanation: Patient confidentiality is essential and should be upheld by doctors and patients. Others can only ever access patient information if they are directly involved in the treatment and their care

questions.text: You should talk to the treating doctor to find out more information
questions.explanation: Same should understand that the doctor treating the patient will also not be able to give out confidential patient information out and asking for it is inappropriate. It is not awful however as Sam himself is not passing on any information

questions.text: It is very bad medical practice to request patient files and you should know better
questions.explanation: While correct in essence, the delivery of this sentiment is very abrasive and may undermine the relationship between Sam and Sureshma

situations.text: A patient tells a medical student, Stuart, that a doctor swears loudly on the ward and he does not want to stay in hospital because of this doctor. Other staff have also noticed this behaviour but are fearful to raise the issue with this doctor. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Stuart when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: The doctor has been working at the hospital for many years
questions.explanation: Irrespective of the doctor’s seniority, if he is swearing and making patients feel uncomfortable, action must be taken

questions.text: The hospital has a no swearing policy
questions.explanation: Hospital policies and guidelines must always be adhered to

questions.text: Other patients may have overheard the doctor swearing loudly
questions.explanation: While possible and potentially important when deciding how to respond, it is based on an assumption

questions.text: Other staff members can report the doctor
questions.explanation: Stuart cannot simply assume that other staff members will take action and must take a proactive approach to the issue at hand

questions.text: There is a complaint process for patients at the hospital that Stuart can guide the patient through
questions.explanation: As the patient feels uncomfortable about the doctor’s profanities, they have the right to utilise the complaint process to vocalise their grievances

situations.text: In order to pass the year, medical students must attend dissection lessons for their specimen’s tutorial. Breanna, a medical student, is panicking – she says to her friend, Dave, that she might faint if she had to enter the room and does not want to dissect a cadaver. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Dave in this situation?

questions.text: Remind Breanna that she needs to complete specimen’s to pass the year
questions.explanation: While not terrible, reminding Breanna how important the sessions are may escalate her anxiety – rather than calm her down

questions.text: Try to help Breanna calm down
questions.explanation: The priority in this scenario is to calm Breanna down so that she can make a rational decision

questions.text: Leave Breanna alone to deal with her anxiety
questions.explanation: Leaving Breanna on her own may allow her negative thoughts to build up, leaving her feeling alone and unsupported

questions.text: Convince Breanna to enter the room to talk to the tutor about her feelings
questions.explanation: By encouraging Breanna to enter the room, it will help her overcome her initial anxieties and she will subsequently be able to vocalise her concerns to the tutor

questions.text: Force Breanna to enter the room
questions.explanation: The choice is Breanna’s and Dave should not force or coerce her to enter the room – only encourage and reassure her

situations.text: James, a medical student, has been awarded a role in the medical society’s end of year play. Upon reading the script, he believes that one of the characters perpetuates racial stereotypes and is offensive. The other actors haven’t said anything about this yet. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Jack when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: That the audience may find it offensive
questions.explanation: If James finds the character offensive, it is likely that others will

questions.text: Other actors haven’t complained so they must not find it offensive
questions.explanation: Other cast members may find it offensive but not have the courage to vocalise this. Even If James only finds it offensive, he still he has the right to vocalise this

questions.text: That James feels uncomfortable performing in a play with this character
questions.explanation: Jack shouldn't have to perform in a play he is uncomfortable with

questions.text: That he only has a minor role in the play and isn’t playing that character
questions.explanation: The size of James’ role in the performance is irrelevant — if he finds this offensive and things others might to, he should vocalise his concerns

questions.text: The fact that if he raises concerns, the other actors might not like it
questions.explanation: This may negatively impact the dynamics of the cast, but this is much less important than preventing people in the audience from being offended

situations.text: A number of university students must work together on a group task. Without consulting the others, Christina immediately volunteers herself as the group leader, decides on the topic and begins to distribute work tasks to the other students. Another student, Bob, is unhappy with Christina’s approach. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Bob in this situation?

questions.text: Suggest that other people should speak up if they want to lead the group
questions.explanation: Part of working as an effective team is ensuring that your voice is heard. Other members of the group should be encouraged to contribute or request to lead the team.

questions.text: Decline to work with Christina
questions.explanation: Declining to cooperate with Christina would be detrimental to the group’s dynamics and will disadvantage the whole team

questions.text: Tell Christina, in front of the group, that she is not giving others a chance to contribute
questions.explanation: While Bob has the right to vocalise his concerns, he should not do so in such a confrontational manner as it may undermine the group’s trust in Christina and affect team dynamics

questions.text: Do not take any action
questions.explanation: If Bob believes that Christina is not allowing other group members contribute as they should, he should raise his concerns

questions.text: Ask another group member to privately tell Christina that she is not giving the other members an adequate chance to contribute
questions.explanation: While this course of action may allow Christina to release the negative impacts of her actions on the group, Bob should take a more proactive approach and not delegate this to another group member (who may not even agree with Bob’s view on the situation)

situations.text: At the emergency department, Nigella, a medical student, is walking through the ward to meet with the doctor. She notices a young girl by herself, distressed and alone. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Nigella in this situation?

questions.text: Take the girl to the playground outside and then meet up with the doctor so she isn’t late
questions.explanation: This doesn't help to resolve the situation and find the girl’s mother. Additionally, the mother might have left her daughter there with the intention of returning shortly

questions.text: Ask a nearby cleaner to tend to the girl
questions.explanation: While this means that Nigella can meet with the doctor and an adult may be supervising the girl, this isn't the cleaner’s responsibility and there is no guarantee that the cleaner will tend to the girl as required

questions.text: Call the doctor and tell him that she will be late
questions.explanation: While timeliness is important, the primary concern here is the welfare of the girl. Calling the doctor and informing him that Nigella will be late is definitely appropriate

questions.text: Provide reassurance to the girl
questions.explanation: As the girl is uncomfortable it is important that Nigella shows empathy and reassures/comforts the girl

questions.text: Ask other staff members if they know where the girl’s mother is
questions.explanation: Although helpful in locating the girl’s mother, Nigella should first seek to tend to the girl, comfort her and ensure that she is safe

situations.text: Benjamin is a medical student. There is a rule that all students should bring their own white coat before entering the laboratory and should not share others’ due to covid protocols. Benjamin realises he has forgotten his white coat and has to enter the laboratory for class. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Natasha when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: That a white coat must be worn before entering
questions.explanation: This guideline is in place to protect medical students and must be obeyed

questions.text: That the tutor is not in the laboratory
questions.explanation: Regardless of whether the tutor is in the laboratory, the rules must be obeyed and Benjamin cannot enter without a white coat

questions.text: Benjamin can rent a white coat from the university
questions.explanation: If Benjamin can access a white coat from elsewhere, without breaking university protocol, he should take that opportunity so that he can enter the laboratory

questions.text: A friend has a spare coat that he can provide to Benjamin
questions.explanation: Although Benjamin’s friend has a spare coat, it is against university protocol to use another student’s (share) coat. Hence, this is not an important consideration

questions.text: There is an unattended coat lying on the floor in front of the lab
questions.explanation: Benjamin should not even consider using that labcoat as it would inevitable belong to another student and may have been left there accidentally

situations.text: Wendy is at a social event with another medical student, Renesa. Renesa confides to her that she has failed the recent exams and will have to repeat the year. Renesa insists that she has been studying hard and that her parents would be very unhappy with her. She is considering dropping out. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Wendy in this situation? Assume that each of the following responses would be said politely

questions.text: Have you asked for advice from tutors/academic staff?
questions.explanation: It is always beneficial to seek advice/clarification from senior members of staff and they could perhaps evaluate Renesa’s circumstances. They may also be useful in providing support/assistance to Renesa

questions.text: You’ll do much better next year, don’t stress
questions.explanation: While this may help to comfort Renesa it misses her primary concerns and does not help her with her decision. A practical comment/solution would be much better.

questions.text: You should try studying science instead – I’ve heard it’s much easier
questions.explanation: Not only is this comment condescending and degrading, it undermines Renesa’s efforts to study medicine and diminishes the value of resilience/persistent – essential traits in the medical profession

questions.text: I believe it would be best to evaluate your options and take some time to come to a decision
questions.explanation: Renesa would undeniably be upset after failing exams and taking action straight away (fuelled by emotion) may lead her to do something that she may regret. Hence, it is very appropriate to advise her to take some time with this decision

questions.text: You should revaluate your study techniques for next year so that you perform better
questions.explanation: While revaluation and introspection are important, it might not have been Renesa’s study techniques that led her to fail the year. Simply assuming this may be perceived as offensive

situations.text: Angelina, a 3rd year medical student, is on a bus to university when suddenly a passenger collapses – appearing unconscious. The bus driver pulls over to the side and asks if there are any passengers with medical qualifications. How important are the following to take into account are the following considerations for Angelina when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: That the life of the passenger is on the line
questions.explanation: This would suggest that the situation is urgent and Angelina, or any other health professions, must act quickly

questions.text: That may be other medically qualified passengers
questions.explanation: While possible, it is not right to assume this, and Angelina should instead proactively respond to help this patient

questions.text: That Angelina is not yet a fully qualified doctor
questions.explanation: While medical students should not overstate their qualifications, this is an emergency situation and even being a medical student Angelyn should come forward in assistance of the passenger. Basic training (such as CPR) may come in handy

questions.text: That the patient may be fine and simply fainted
questions.explanation: It is incorrect to assume that the patient simply has a minor ailment – the situation should be treated as urgent

questions.text: That Angelina doesn’t know the unconscious individual personally
questions.explanation: Regardless of whether she knows the individual, she should strive to evaluate the situation and provide assistance if necessary

situations.text: Two university students, Jade and Jan, have a group project that they have to deliver today. An hour before this, Jan calls Jade saying that he won’t be able to present the project. When asked why, Jan responds by saying that he has taken illicit drugs this morning and is not in a state to present. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Jade when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: The task must be presented today by both group members and Jan should attend
questions.explanation: While this is true, the welfare of Jan and other students must be prioritised. It may be unsafe and unfeasible for him to commute to university

questions.text: Determining whether Jan needs support/help regarding his drug usage
questions.explanation: Illicit drug usage is a major issue and will likely contradict university policy. It is important that Jan gets the help that he needs

questions.text: That the tutor is made aware about this situation, with the consent of Jan
questions.explanation: If Jan allows, informing the tutor may help ensure that Jade isn’t unfairly disadvantaged and, by reaching out to a member of staff, Jan may be directed to the help he needs

questions.text: That other students are made aware of Jan’s drug usage
questions.explanation: Jan might not want this to pass to other students and making other students aware is only likely to have negative ramifications

questions.text: That Chris does not interact with other students or present if he is not in a condition to do so
questions.explanation: The welfare of Chris and the other students should be the priority and he should not commute to the university and interact with others if he isn’t in a state to do so

situations.text: While on a placement with another medical student, Adam, Yifan hears from him that he cheated in the end of year exams. While they are good friends, Yifan is taken aback by this. She recalls the university’s strict no cheating policy. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Yifan when deciding how to respond to the situation.

questions.text: The exam was sat a number of months ago
questions.explanation: Regardless of how long ago it was, cheating/plagiarism and any other dishonest practice must be reported

questions.text: David’s feelings if he found out Yifan reported him
questions.explanation: David’s emotions are frankly unimportant in this scenario – as university policy takes precedence here

questions.text: Whether there is proof of David’s dishonest practice
questions.explanation: All allegations must be backed up by supporting evidence; without it, the allegation cannot be corroborated

questions.text: The potential that David is just joking to elicit a reaction from Yifan
questions.explanation: Although this might be a possibility, if there is even the potential for this dishonest practice, it must be followed up. Yifan cannot assume David is joking

questions.text: That David is generally honest and righteous
questions.explanation: While this may be the case, the fact that he has admitted to dishonest practice necessitates further investigation – regardless of his persona

situations.text: A medical student is tasked with conducting an interview on a patient – to determine the history of their presenting complain. When the GP enters the room, he is met by the patient who appears to be very angry. He said that he has been asking to see a proper doctor for a long time and the medical student was rude and not helpful at all. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Dr Burns in this situation?

questions.text: Ask the patient why he found the medical student rude and unhelpful
questions.explanation: It is essential for the GP to hear out the patients claims and determine whether there has been any misconduct

questions.text: Tell the medical student to leave the room
questions.explanation: This insinuates that the medical student has acted wrongly and does not give an opportunity for the student to explain their perspective

questions.text: Tell the patient that they are overreacting
questions.explanation: The patient has the right to complain and the doctor should not tell him otherwise – instead the doctor should seek to gain more insight into the patient’s complaint

questions.text: Advise the patient to complain via the practice’s complaint process
questions.explanation: While it is appropriate to direct patient’s to the relevant complaint process, the doctor should also seek to hear out their concerns

questions.text: Try to calm down and placate the irate patient
questions.explanation: The doctor should definitely attempt to diffuse the situation as a matter of priority to prevent its escalation
